bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, May 26, 1951

div1.p: Truby is extremely critical of Standlee's manuscript, and believes that she is not competent to write an accurate account. He encloses a copy of his letter to her.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, May 26, 1951
div1.opener:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO 18, CALIFORNIA
May/26/51
Dear Dr Hench.
div1.p:
Mrs T, Elizabeth & I all enjoyed
your fine, newsy letter of the 18th. I don't
blame you a bit for being proud of those
talented “Kids”. Even I like to boast about
mine. You have met one of them and I do
hope you will meet my other two - Barbara and
Jack. The latter was 6 ft 1 in when he left home
at 17 to enter West Point. He is now a Capt. of
Infantry, stationed at 71 Bragg. N.C., commands
a Company of Infantry paratroopers, and of
course is one himself. At West Point he
made the swimming team in his plebe year and
was on that until he graduated. During his
last year his team won the intercollegiate
swimming championship defeating Yale, who
still had that great champion from the Canal
Zone (can't think of his name) That was the first
time West Point ever won in swimming. So
“little me” is proud as a Pop-too. Oh! about
Barbara. She was the red haired beauty of
the family, a fine horsewoman and often rode
in Col Patton's (The famous hero of World War II)
horse shows at Ft Myer Va. She married
Col LaGarde's son, and lives in Maryland.
There that is all on that subject.

Thanks for the reprints (yf episode) I appreciate
AC
Tr
them very much and they will land in
good hands where they will be much appreciated
Will enclose copy of my reply to Mrs. Standle's request
for haste on Chapter III of her story. I could
not take it, and am so happy that I exploded
for it was not possible for me to wade
through the voluminous mms. and comment on
things that I know more about them she ever
will. As you will see, nearly all of the answers to of her errors
in the yf. episode could easily be found
in my book. She either had not read the
book or some one or some one had made
her think it was not a trustworthy source
of information on the subject. When she quoted
Hemmeter on what Dr Welch had said about
Carroll and omited to quote the nice things
Welch & other great men said about Reed
in the Senate Document, I knew it was
time for me to withdraw all connection
with her story. I was really nervous
and completely upset but as you see I
am back again on an even Keel. I hope
she will see the light and not try to
solve the controversies of yf., but leave it
to you as I suggested. To write a history
about a discredited hero with such grand
memorial as the W.R Q.H would be a force.

I have been swamped with work but begin
to see the light. I have done this in haste
for I know I have neglected you very much
lately. We all send our greetings and know
you will enjoy all the grand doings with your
“kids” in June.
